m_DescList: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is the foundational protocol for data interaction between browsers and servers. <color=#3c3cff>http://</color><color=#666666>google.com</color> represents the essence of this protocol.
Essentially, this protocol transmits specially formatted text to servers, which parse this text and respond based on the requested content.
For example, here is a client request:
GET /extensions/marketplace.json HTTP/1.1
Host: main.vscode-cdn.net
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Code/1.99.3 Chrome/132.0.6834.210 Electron/34.3.2 Safari/537.36
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br, zstd
<color=#ee3300>GET</color> indicates the request type. HTTP supports multiple types: GET, POST, DELETE...
<color=#3c3cff>/extensions/marketplace.json</color> is the requested URL
<color=#e06600>HTTP/1.1</color> specifies the HTTP version
<color=#ee3300>Host: </color> denotes the host address parameter
<color=#3c3cff>main.vscode-cdn.net</color> is the target host
<color=#ee3300>User-Agent: </color> indicates the browser information parameter
<color=#3c3cff>Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Code/1.99.3 Chrome/132.0.6834.210 Electron/34.3.2 Safari/537.36</color> details the browser
<color=#ee3300>Accept-Encoding: </color> specifies acceptable encodings
<color=#3c3cff>gzip, deflate, br, zstd</color> lists supported encodings
Now we aim to extract common fields from HTTP requests:
1. Capture group for URL named "url"
2. Capture group for host address named "host"
3. Capture group for browser info named "user_agent"
4. Capture group for encoding info named "accept_encoding"
5. If a line contains capture groups, match the entire line
Construct a regex that passes all tests on the right.
